answers.answer: Hi!I am not sure what exactly happened. However, maybe when the first X-ray was taken the bone was in process of healing. Thereafter the weight on the leg may have caused the fracture segments to move apart. There can be non-union too due to different causes such as ow blood supply, poor mineralization, presence of diabetes, presence of infection, poor alignment, or too much space between the fracture ends. This is treated by bone grafts, immobilization with plates and screws, or removal of scarred tissue from fractured ends. Basically all these processes need surgery. Consult your orthopedic surgeon for a confirmed diagnosis. Take care!The medical advice given should not be considered a substitute for medical care provided by a doctor who can examine you. The advice may not be completely correct for you as the doctor cannot examine you and does not know your complete medical history. Hence this reply to your post should only be considered as a guiding line and you must consult your doctor at the earliest for your medical problem.
